{{globalize|date=October 2014}} [[File:Silence and Respect.jpg|thumb|right|A sign entreating "silence and respect" at [[Arlington National Cemetery]]]] '''Respect''' is a positive feeling or action shown towards someone or something considered important, or held in high esteem or regard; it conveys a sense of admiration for good or valuable qualities; and it is also the process of honoring someone by exhibiting care, concern, or consideration for their needs or feelings.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/respect|title=Definition of RESPECT|work=Merriam Webster|accessdate = December 13, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://dictionary.cambridge.org/us/dictionary/english/respect|title=Definition of "respect"|work=Cambridge Dictionary|accessdate = December 13, 2017}}</ref>
Some people may earn the respect of individuals by assisting others or by playing important social roles. In many cultures, individuals are considered to be worthy of respect until they prove otherwise. Courtesies that show respect include simple words and phrases like "thank you" in the West, simple physical [[gesture]]s like a slight bow in the East, a smile, or direct eye contact, or a simple handshake.
== Signs and other ways of knowing respect ==
=== Language ===
Respect is shown in many different languages by following certain grammatical conventions, especially in referring to individuals.
An [[honorific]] is a word or expression (often a [[pronoun]]) that shows respect when used in addressing or referring to a person or animal.
Typically honorifics are used for second and third persons; use for first person is less common. Some languages have anti-honorific first person forms (like "your most humble servant" or "this unworthy person") whose effect is to enhance the relative honor accorded a second or third person.
For instance, it is disrespectful to not use polite language and honorifics when speaking in Japanese with someone having a higher social status. The Japanese honorific "san" can be used when speaking English.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fodors.com/world/asia/japan/tokyo/features.html|title=Top Experiences in Tokyo - Fodor's Travel|website=www.fodors.com|accessdate=22 October 2017}}</ref>
In China it is rude to call someone by their first name unless you have known them for a long period of time. In work-related situations, people address each other by their title. At home people often refer to each other by nicknames or terms of kinship.<ref name=autogenerated1> [http://www.protocolprofessionals.com/articles_china.htm Protocol Professionals, Inc. | Chinese Etiquette & Protocol]</ref> In the Chinese culture, individuals often address their friends as juniors and seniors even if they are just a few months younger or older. When a Chinese person asks someone their age they often do this so they know how to address the person.<ref name=autogenerated1 />
=== Physical gestures === {{See also|Category:Gestures of respect}}
[[File: Westindischer Maler um 1530 001.jpg|thumb|180px|right|A wife touching the feet of her husband.]]
In Islamic cultures around the world, there are many ways to show respect to people. For example, it is recommended to kiss the hands of parents, grandparents and teachers. Also, it is narrated in the sayings of Muhammad that if a person looks at the faces of parents and teachers with a smile, he will definitely be rewarded by Allah with success and happiness.
In [[India]], it is customary that, out of respect, when a person's foot accidentally touches a book or any written material (considered to be a manifestations of [[Saraswati]], the goddess of knowledge) or another person's leg, it will be followed by an apology in the form of a single hand gesture ([[Pranāma]]) with the right hand, where the offending person first touches the object with the finger tips and then the forehead and/or chest. This also counts for money, which is considered to be a manifestation of the goddess of wealth [[Lakshmi]].<ref>DeBruyn, Pippa; Bain, Keith; Venkatraman, Niloufer (2010). ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=qG-9cwHOcCIC Frommer's India]''. pp. 76.</ref> Pranāma, or the touching of feet in Indian culture is a sign of respect. For instance, when a child is greeting his or her grandparent, they typically will touch their hands to their grandparents' feet. In Indian culture, it is believed that the feet are a source of power and love.<ref>Chatterjee, Gautam (2001). ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=NQ0XQHEkuIcC Sacred Hindu Symbols]''. pp. 47-48.</ref>
In many African/West Indian descent communities and some non-African//West Indian descent communities, respect can be signified by the touching of fists.
Many gestures or physical acts that are common in the West can be considered disrespectful in Japan. For instance, one should not point directly at someone.<ref name="fodors.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.fodors.com/world/asia/japan/tokyo/feature_30007.html|title=Lodging Options - Experience Tokyo|date=31 October 2007|website=archive.org|accessdate=22 October 2017|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071031054529/http://www.fodors.com/world/asia/japan/tokyo/feature_30007.html|archivedate=31 October 2007|df=}}</ref> When greeting someone or thanking them, it may be insulting if the person of lower status does not bow lower than the person with higher status. The duration and level of the bow depends on many factors such as age and status.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://westsidetoastmasters.com/resources/book_of_body_language/chap5.html|title=Cultural Variations In Body Language|website=westsidetoastmasters.com|accessdate=22 October 2017}}</ref> Some signs of physical respect apply to women only. If a woman does not wear cosmetics or a brassiere, it is possible that she will be considered unprofessional or others may think she does not care about the situation.<ref name="fodors.com"/>
==== Chinese culture ==== {{See also|Category:Chinese honorifics}}
Unlike Japanese culture, it is not necessary in Chinese culture to bow to one another as a greeting or parting gesture. Bowing is generally reserved as a sign of respect for elders and ancestors. When bowing, they place the fist of the right hand in the palm of their left at stomach level. The deeper the bow, the more respect they are showing.
In Chinese culture, there is not much participation in physical contact, especially when doing business because this can be seen as too casual, thus disrespectful. It is considered rude to slap, pat, or put one's arm around the shoulders of another.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.commisceo-global.com/country-guides/china-guide|title=China - Language, Culture, Customs and Etiquette|website=www.commisceo-global.com|accessdate=22 October 2017}}</ref> However, [[affection]] in same-sex [[friendships]] in East Asia is much more pronounced than in the West. Same-sex friends will often be seen with their arms around one another, holding hands, and other signs of physical affection.<ref>Kline, et al. "Communicating love: Comparisons between American and East Asian university students." ''International Journal of Intercultural Relations''. no. 32 (2008): 200-2014.</ref>
It is uncommon to see very many hand gestures being used in Chinese culture because this is often considered to be excessive. <ref name=autogenerated1 /> The Chinese sometimes do not smile or exchange greetings with strangers. Smiling or being friendly to someone you do not know well can be considered rude and too familiar. It is also common to see Chinese women covering their mouths when they laugh. Traditionally, a woman who laughed too loudly was considered to be uncouth and ill-bred.<ref name=autogenerated1 />
Traditionally, there was not much hand-shaking in Chinese culture. However, this gesture is now widely practiced among men, especially when greeting Westerners or other foreigners. Many Westerners may find Chinese handshakes to be too long or too weak, but this is because a weaker handshake is a gesture of humility and respect.<ref name=autogenerated1 />
[[Kowtowing]], or kneeling and bowing so deeply that one's forehead is touching the floor, is practiced during worship at temples. Kowtowing is a powerful gesture reserved mainly for honoring the dead or offering deep respect at a temple.<ref name=autogenerated1 />
Many codes of behavior revolve around young people showing respect to older people. Like in many cultures, younger Chinese individuals are expected to defer to older people, let them speak first, sit down after them and not contradict them. Sometimes when an older person enters a room, everyone stands. People are often introduced from oldest to youngest. Often time, younger people will go out of their way to open doors for their elders and not cross their legs in front of them. The older you are the more respect you are expected to be treated with.<ref name=autogenerated1 />
== Respect as a cultural value== [[File:Respeitoplaca.JPG|right|thumb|200px|[[Sign]] in [[São João da Barra]] saying ''"respect if you want to be respected"''.]]
=== Indigenous American culture === In many [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|indigenous American societies]] the perspective on respect differs slightly because it serves as an important concept valued in their culture's context. Aside from meaning positive feelings of esteem or deference is also viewed as a moral value that teaches indigenous individuals about their culture.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Fernandez|first1=David-Lorente|title=Ser respetuoso es ser persona. El niño y la pedagogía moral de Los Nahuas del Centro de México|journal=Revista de Dialectología y Tradiciones Populares|date=2012|volume=67|issue=2|pages=431|doi=10.3989/rdtp.2012.16}}</ref> In addition, this moral value is treated as a process that influences certain participation in the community and also helps the individual develop and become integrated into their culture's community. During childhood is when this value of respect is taught because indigenous children participating in and learning about their community is an important aspect of the culture.
Respect as a form of behavior and participation is especially important in childhood as it serves as a basis of how the child must conduct themselves in their community. Children engage in mature activities such as cooking for the family, cleaning and sweeping the house, caring for infant peers, and crop work. Indigenous children learn to view their participation in these activities are a representation of respect. Through his manner of participation of activities of respect is how children not only learn about culture but also practice it as well.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://usa.gov|title=Official Guide to Government Information and Services - USAGov|website=usa.gov|accessdate=22 October 2017}}</ref>
=== Respect for Authority (Christianity) ===
The Christian faith specifically recognizes respect for Authority throughout the Bible, including parental authority ([[Ten Commandments|Ten Commandments]]), civil authority and divine authority.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.truthmagazine.com/archives/volume33/GOT033159.html|title=Respect for Authority|website=truthmagazine.com|accessdate=14 September 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/bitesize/guides/zfhf9j6/revision/1 |title=Sources of Authority |newspaper=[[BBC]] |accessdate=October 28, 2018 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
= <small>1 Timothy 2:1-4 New American Standard Bible (NASB)</small> = First of all, then, I urge that entreaties ''and'' prayers, petitions ''and'' thanksgivings, be made on behalf of all men, for kings and all who are in <sup>[a]</sup>authority, so that we may lead a tranquil and quiet life in all godliness and <sup>[b]</sup>dignity. This is good and acceptable in the sight of God our Savior, who desires all men to be saved and to come to the <sup>[c]</sup>knowledge of the truth.

''Cyclonopedia''{{cite web|url=http://re-press.org/books/cyclonopedia-complicity-with-anonymous-materials/ |title=Cyclonopedia: Complicity with Anonymous Materials | |publisher=Re-press.org |date= |accessdate=2013-12-24}} ==Philosophical work== Negarestani has been a regular contributor to ''[[Collapse (journal)|Collapse]]'', as well as other print and web publications such as [[Ctheory]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ctheory.net/articles.aspx?id=396 |title=CTheory.net |publisher=CTheory.net |date= |accessdate=2013-12-24}} On March 11, 2011, faculty from [[Brooklyn College]] and [[The New School]] organized a symposium to discuss Cyclonopedia titled Leper Creativity.{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/details/LeperCreativityCyclonopediaSymposium4thPanel |title=Leper Creativity: Cyclonopedia Symposium : Free Download & Streaming : Internet Archive |publisher=Archive.org |date= |accessdate=2013-12-24}} Later on in the year, [[Punctum books]] published a book with the same title that included essays, articles, artworks, and documents from or related to the symposium.{{cite web|url=http://punctumbooks.com/titles/leper-creativity-cyclonopedia-symposium/ |title=Leper Creativity: Cyclonopedia Symposium |publisher=punctum books |date= |accessdate=2013-12-24}} In 2011, he co-edited Collapse's issue VII with Robin Mackay titled Culinary Materialism {{cite web|url=http://www.urbanomic.com/pub_collapse7.php |title=Collapse Vol. VII: Culinary Materialism |publisher=Urbanomic |date= |accessdate=2013-12-24}} In 2012, Negarestani collaborated with Florian Hecker on an artwork titled "Chimerization" that was included in the [[dOCUMENTA (13)]] exhibition.http://d13.documenta.de/#/programs/the-kassel-programs/some-artworks-and-programs-initiated-by-documenta-13-participants/chimerizations-and-speculative-solutions/ He has since written librettos for a series of full-length albums based on Hecker's concept of 'chimerization'. After being associated with the philosophical movement of [[speculative realism]] for several years, Negarestani is currently lecturing and writing about [[Rationalism|rationalist]] universalism beginning with the evolution of the modern system of knowledge and advancing toward contemporary philosophies of rationalism, their procedures as well as their demands for special forms of human conduct. Since his relocation to the [[United States of America]], Negarestani has given several lectures, a list of which includes: * The Human Centipede, A View From the Art World, in Escape Velocities symposium: E-flux, New York, November 13, 2013 {{cite web|url=http://www.e-flux.com/program/escape-velocities-2/ |title=Escape Velocities: Symposium at |publisher=e-flux |date= |accessdate=2013-12-24}}* A Script for Synthesis, collaboration with Florian Hecker: PERFORMA 13, Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, New York, November 9, 2013 {{cite web|url=http://13.performa-arts.org/event/florian-hecker |title=Performa 13 · Event · Florian Hecker |publisher=13.performa-arts.org |date= |accessdate=2013-12-24}} * The Labour of the Inhuman: [[Independent Curators International (ICI)]] Curatorial Hub, New York, September 24, 2013 {{cite web|url=http://curatorsintl.org/events/dark-trajectories-politics-of-the-outside |title=Independent Curators International - Dark Trajectories: Politics of the Outside |publisher=Curatorsintl.org |date= |accessdate=2013-12-24}} * Blow Your Mind: On Freedom and Enlightenment, with Ray Brassier and Suhail Malik, 88 Eldridge Street, 4th floor, New York, July 20, 2013 {{cite web|url=http://happyhr.org |title=Happy Hour |publisher=Happyhr.org |date=2013-07-20 |accessdate=2013-12-24}} * Via Finitude, A reconstruction of Nicole Oresme's diagrams: Western University, London, Ontario, May 28, 2013 {{cite web|url=https://archive.org/details/RezaNegarestani |title=Reza Negarestani @ Western University : Free Download & Streaming : Internet Archive |publisher=Archive.org |date=2001-03-10 |accessdate=2013-12-24}} * Sonic Practice, Discourse and Auditory Experimentation, with Guerino Mazzola: Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, May 9, 2013 {{cite web|url=http://act.mit.edu/projects-and-events/events/public-programs/may-9-guerino-mazzola-reza-negarestani-sonic-practice-discourse-and-auditory-experimentation/ |title=Guerino Mazzola & Reza Negarestani Sonic Practice, Discourse and Auditory Experimentation - ACT at MIT |publisher=Act.mit.edu |date=2013-05-09 |accessdate=2013-12-24}} * Theory-fiction as Philosophy's Minecraft: University of Pennsylvania, Kelly Writers House, Philadelphia, March 28, 2013 {{cite web|url=http://writing.upenn.edu/wh/calendar/0313.php |title=March 2013 |publisher=Writing.upenn.edu |date=2013-03-31 |accessdate=2013-12-24}} * The Topos of the Earth: City University of New York, NEW YORK, February 21, 2013 {{cite web|author=Username * |url=http://centerforthehumanities.org/james-gallery/events/The-Topos-of-the-Earth-Telescopic-and-Stereoscopic-Visions-of-the-Abyss-in-One |title=CUNY Center for the Humanities |publisher=Centerforthehumanities.org |date=2013-02-21 |accessdate=2013-12-24}} * Abducting the Outside: Modernity and the Culture of Acceleration: Miguel Abreu Gallery, New York, November 18, 2012 {{cite web|url=http://www.miguelabreugallery.com/events/2012_NovemberEvents/Nov18_Negarestani/01.htm |title=Reza Negarestani |publisher=Miguelabreugallery.com |date=2012-11-18 |accessdate=2013-12-24}} * The Non-Trivial Goat and the Cliffs of the Universal, with Florian Hecker: Abrons’ Playhouse, New York, Nov 15, 2012 {{cite web|author=11/15/12 |url=http://issueprojectroom.org/drupal/event/reza-negarestani-florian-hecker |title=Reza Negarestani & Florian Hecker: The Non-Trivial Goat and the Cliffs of the Universal |publisher=ISSUE Project Room |date=2012-11-15 |accessdate=2013-12-24}} Negarestani's current blog, [https://toyphilosophy.com/ Toy Philosophy], "focus[es] on various threads - some still loose and some already converged - of [his] philosophical research" {{cite web|url=https://toyphilosophy.com/2018/01/24/returning-to-the-age-of-blogging/ |title=Returning to the Age of Blogging |publisher=toyphilosophy.com |date=2018-01-24 |accessdate=2018-04-02}} ==Bibliography== ===Books=== *''[http://re-press.org/books/cyclonopedia-complicity-with-anonymous-materials/ Cyclonopedia: Complicity with Anonymous Materials]'' (Re.Press, 2008) *''[https://www.urbanomic.com/the_mortiloquis/ The Mortiloquist: A Barbaric Interpretation of the Life and Problems of Western Philosophy]'' (Urbanomic, 2012) *(ed. w/ [https://www.gold.ac.uk/visual-cultures/staff/mackay-robin/ Robin Mackay]) ''[https://www.urbanomic.com/book/collapse-7/ Collapse Volume VII: Culinary Materialism]'' (Urbanomic, 2012) *''[https://www.urbanomic.com/book/torture-concrete/ Torture Concrete: Jean-Luc Moulène and the Protocol of Abstraction]'' (Sequence Press, 2014) *''[https://www.urbanomic.com/book/intelligence-and-spirit/ Intelligence and Spirit]'' (Urbanomic x Sequence Press, 2018) ===Articles and short stories=== *''The Militarization of Peace: Absence of Terror or Terror of Absence?'' '''Self-compassion''' is extending [[compassion]] to one's self in instances of perceived inadequacy, failure, or general [[suffering]]. [[Kristin Neff]] has defined self-compassion as being composed of three main components – self-kindness, common humanity, and [[mindfulness]].<ref name="neff-a">{{cite journal | doi = 10.1080/15298860309027 | last1 = Neff | first1 = K. D. | year = 2003a | title = The development and validation of a scale to measure self-compassion | url = | journal = Self and Identity | volume = 2 | issue = 3| pages = 223–250 | citeseerx = 10.1.1.362.5757 }}</ref>
*Self-kindness: Self-compassion [[logical consequence|entails]] being warm towards oneself when encountering pain and personal shortcomings, rather than ignoring them or hurting oneself with self-criticism. *Common humanity: Self-compassion also involves recognizing that suffering and personal failure is part of the shared human experience. *[[Mindfulness]]: Self-compassion requires taking a balanced approach to one's negative emotions so that feelings are neither suppressed nor exaggerated. Negative thoughts and emotions are observed with openness, so that they are held in mindful awareness. Mindfulness is a non-judgmental, receptive mind state in which individuals observe their thoughts and feelings as they are, without trying to suppress or deny them.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1037/0022-3514.84.4.822 | last1 = Brown | first1 = K. W. | last2 = Ryan | first2 = R. M. | year = 2003 | title = The benefits of being present: Mindfulness and its role in psychological well-being | url = | journal = Journal of Personality and Social Psychology | volume = 84 | issue = 4| pages = 822–848 | pmid = 12703651 | citeseerx = 10.1.1.331.8033 }}</ref> Conversely, mindfulness requires that one not be "over-identified" with mental or emotional phenomena, so that one suffers aversive reactions.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Bishop | first1 = S. R. | last2 = Lau | first2 = M. | last3 = Shapiro | first3 = S. | last4 = Carlson | first4 = L. | last5 = Anderson | first5 = N. D. | last6 = Carmody | first6 = J. | last7 = Segal | first7 = Z. V. Abbey | last8 = Speca | first8 = M. | last9 = Velting | first9 = D. Devins| year = 2004 | title = Mindfulness: A Proposed Operational Definition | url = | journal = Clinical Psychology Science and Practice | volume = 11 | issue = | pages = 191–206 |display-authors=etal}}</ref> This latter type of response involves narrowly focusing and ruminating on one's negative emotions.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1037/0021-843X.100.4.569 | last1 = Nolen-Hoeksema | first1 = S. | year = 1991 | title = Responses to depression and their effects on the duration of depressive episodes | url = | journal = Journal of Abnormal Psychology | volume = 100 | issue = 4| pages = 569–582 | pmid = 1757671 }}</ref>
Self-compassion has been considered to resemble [[Carl Rogers]]' notion of "[[unconditional positive regard]]" applied both towards clients and oneself; [[Albert Ellis]]' "unconditional self-acceptance"; Maryhelen Snyder's notion of an "internal empathizer" that explored one's own experience with "curiosity and compassion"; [[Ann Weiser Cornell]]'s notion of a [[Inner Relationship Focusing#Description|gentle, allowing relationship]] with all parts of one's being; and [[Judith V. Jordan|Judith Jordan]]'s concept of ''self-empathy'', which implies acceptance, care and [[empathy]] towards the self.<ref>Gary Buck, David Lukoff: [http://www.spiritualcompetency.com/scrcQuiz.aspx?courseID=65 Self-Compassion i: Spiritual and Psychological Roots] (course description), SCRC</ref>
Self-compassion is different from [[self-pity]], a state of mind or emotional response of a person believing to be a victim and lacking the confidence and competence to [[Coping (psychology)|cope]] with an adverse situation.
Research indicates that self-compassionate individuals experience greater [[psychological health]] than those who lack self-compassion. For example, self-compassion is positively associated with [[life satisfaction]], [[wisdom]], [[happiness]], [[optimism]], [[curiosity]], learning goals, [[social connectedness]], personal responsibility, and [[emotional resilience]]. At the same time, it is associated with a lower tendency for [[self-criticism]], depression, [[anxiety]], [[Rumination (psychology)|rumination]], [[thought suppression]], [[perfectionism (psychology)|perfectionism]], and disordered eating attitudes.<ref name="neff-a" /><ref>Adams, C. E., & Leary, M. R. (in press). Promoting Self-compassionate Attitudes toward Eating Among Restrictive and Guilty Eaters. ''Journal of Social and Clinical Psychology.''</ref><ref>Gilbert, & Irons, 2005</ref><ref name="leary">{{cite journal | doi = 10.1037/0022-3514.92.5.887 | last1 = Leary | first1 = M. R. | last2 = Tate | first2 = E. B. | last3 = Adams | first3 = C. E. | last4 = Allen | first4 = A. B. | last5 = Hancock | first5 = J. | year = 2007 | title = Self-compassion and reactions to unpleasant self-relevant events: The implications of treating oneself kindly | url = | journal = Journal of Personality and Social Psychology | volume = 92 | issue = 5| pages = 887–904 | pmid = 17484611 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1080/13576500444000317 | last1 = Neff | first1 = K. D. | last2 = Hseih | first2 = Y. | last3 = Dejitthirat | first3 = K. | year = 2005 | title = Self-compassion, achievement goals, and coping with academic failure | url = | journal = Self and Identity | volume = 4 | issue = 3| pages = 263–287 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1016/j.jrp.2006.03.004 | last1 = Neff | first1 = K. D. | last2 = Kirkpatrick | first2 = K. | last3 = Rude | first3 = S. D. | last2 = Rude | first2 = S. S. | last3 = Kirkpatrick | first3 = K. | year = 2007 | title = An examination of self-compassion in relation to positive psychological functioning and personality traits | url = | journal = Journal of Research in Personality | volume = 41 | issue = 4| pages = 908–916 }}</ref>
Self-compassion has different effects than [[self-esteem]], a subjective emotional evaluation of the self. Although psychologists extolled the benefits of self-esteem for many years, recent research has exposed costs associated with the pursuit of high self-esteem,<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1037/0033-2909.130.3.392 | last1 = Crocker | first1 = J. | last2 = Park | first2 = L. E. | year = 2004 | title = The costly pursuit of self-esteem | url = | journal = Psychological Bulletin | volume = 130 | issue = 3| pages = 392–414 | pmid = 15122925 }}</ref> including [[narcissism]],<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1037/0022-3514.75.1.219 | last1 = Bushman | first1 = B. J. | last2 = Baumeister | first2 = R. F. | year = 1998 | title = Threatened egotism, narcissism, self-esteem, and direct and displaced aggression: Does self-love or self-hate lead to violence? | url = | journal = Journal of Personality and Social Psychology | volume = 75 | issue = 1| pages = 219–229 | pmid = 9686460 | citeseerx = 10.1.1.337.396 }}</ref> distorted self-perceptions,<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1037/0022-3514.65.2.317 | last1 = Sedikides | first1 = C. | year = 1993 | title = Assessment, enhancement, and verification determinants of the self-evaluation process | url = | journal = Journal of Personality and Social Psychology | volume = 65 | issue = 2| pages = 317–338 }}</ref> contingent and/or unstable self-worth,<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1037/0033-295X.108.3.593 | last1 = Crocker | first1 = J. | last2 = Wolfe | first2 = C. T. | year = 2001 | title = Contingencies of self-worth | url = | journal = Psychological Review | volume = 108 | issue = 3| pages = 593–623 | pmid = 11488379 }}</ref> as well as anger and violence toward those who threaten the ego.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1037/0033-295X.103.1.5 | last1 = Baumeister | first1 = R. F. | last2 = Smart | first2 = L. | last3 = Boden | first3 = J. M. | year = 1996 | title = Relation of threatened egotism to violence and aggression: The dark side of high self-esteem | url = | journal = Psychological Review | volume = 103 | issue = 1| pages = 5–33 | pmid = 8650299 | citeseerx = 10.1.1.1009.3747 }}</ref> It appears that self-compassion offers the same mental health benefits as self-esteem, but with fewer of its drawbacks such as narcissism, [[Narcissistic rage and narcissistic injury|ego-defensive anger]], inaccurate self-perceptions, self-worth contingency, or social comparison.<ref name="leary" /><ref>Neff, K. D & Vonk, R. (submitted). ''Self-compassion versus self-esteem: Two different ways of relating to oneself.'' Manuscript submitted for publication.</ref>
== Scales == Much of the research conducted on self-compassion so far has used the Self-Compassion Scale, created by [[Kristin Neff]], which measures the degree to which individuals display self-kindness against self-judgment, common humanity versus [[Isolation (psychology)|isolation]], and [[mindfulness]] versus over-identification.<ref name=":2" />
The Self-Compassion Scale has been translated into different languages. Some of these include a Czech,<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Benda | first1 = J. | last2 = Reichová | first2 = A. | year = 2016 | title = Psychometric characteristics of the Czech version of the Self-Compassion Scale (SCS- CZ) | journal = Československá Psychologie | volume = 60 | issue = 2 | pages = 120–136 }}</ref> Dutch,<ref name=":1" /> Japanese,<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Arimitsu | first1 = K | year = 2014 | title = Development and validation of the japanese version of the self-compassion scale | url = | journal = Japanese Journal of Psychology | volume = 85 | issue = 1| pages = 50–59 | doi=10.4992/jjpsy.85.50}}</ref> Chinese,<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Chen | first1 = J. | last2 = Yan | first2 = L. | last3 = Zhou | first3 = L. | year = 2011 | title = Reliability and validity of chinese version of self-compassion scale | url = | journal = Chinese Journal of Clinical Psychology | volume = 19 | issue = 6| pages = 734–736 }}</ref> Turkish<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Deniz | first1 = M. E. | last2 = Kesici | first2 = Ş. | last3 = Sümer | first3 = A. S. | year = 2008 | title = The validity and reliability of the turkish version of the self-compassion scale | url = | journal = Social Behavior and Personality | volume = 36 | issue = 9| pages = 1151–1160 | doi=10.2224/sbp.2008.36.9.1151}}</ref> and Greek<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Mantzios | first1 = M. | last2 = Wilson | first2 = J. C. | last3 = Giannou | first3 = K. | year = 2015 | title = Psychometric properties of the greek versions of the self-compassion and mindful attention and awareness scales | url = | journal = Mindfulness | volume = 6 | issue = 1| pages = 123–132 | doi=10.1007/s12671-013-0237-3}}</ref> version.
=== Development === The original sample for which the scale was developed consisted of 68 undergraduate students from a large university in the United States. In this experiment, the participants narrowed down the potential scale items to 71.<ref name=":2">{{cite journal | last1 = Neff | first1 = K. D. | year = 2003a | title = The development and validation of a scale to measure self-compassion | url = | journal = Self and Identity | volume = 2 | issue = 3| pages = 223–250 | doi=10.1080/15298860309027| citeseerx = 10.1.1.362.5757 }}</ref>
The next stage of development involved testing the [[Reliability (psychometrics)|reliability]] and [[Validity (statistics)|validity]] of the scale among a larger group of participants. During this research study, 391 undergraduate students were selected at random to complete the 71 previously narrowed down scale items.<ref name=":2" /> Based on their results, the number of items was reduced to 26.<ref name=":2" /> The self-compassion scales have good reliability and validity.<ref name="Van Dam">{{cite journal | last1 = Van Dam | first1 = N. T. | last2 = Sheppard | first2 = S.C. | last3 = Forsyth | first3 = J.P. | last4 = Earleywine | first4 = M. | year = 2011 | title = Self-compassion is a better predictor than mindfulness of symptom severity and quality of life in mixed anxiety and depression | doi = 10.1016/j.janxdis.2010.08.011 | pmid = 20832990 | journal = Journal of Anxiety Disorders | volume = 25 | issue = 1| pages = 123–30 }}</ref>
A second study was conducted to look more closely at the difference between [[self-esteem]] and self-compassion. This study consisted of 232 randomly selected, undergraduate students.<ref name=":2" /> Participants were asked to complete a number of different scales in [[questionnaire]] form. They were as follows: The 26-item Self-compassion Scale, the 10-item [[Rosenberg self-esteem scale|Rosenberg Self-esteem Scale]], the 10-item Self-determination Scale, the 21-item Basic Psychological Needs Scale, and the 40-item [[Narcissistic Personality Inventory]].<ref name=":2" /> Based on the findings, Neff reports "that self-compassion and [[self-esteem]] were measuring two different psychological phenomena."<ref name=":2" />
A third study was conducted to examine the [[construct validity]]. By comparing two different groups of people, researchers would be able to see the different levels of self-compassion. Forty-three [[Buddhism|Buddhist]] practitioners completed the Self-compassion Scale as well as a [[self-esteem]] scale.<ref name=":2" /> The sample of 232 undergraduate students from the second study was used as the comparison group. As expected by Neff, the Buddhist practitioners had significantly higher self-compassion scores than the students.<ref name=":2" />
=== Self-compassion scale === The long version of the Self-compassion scale (SCS) consists of 26 items. This includes 6 subscales – self-kindness, self-judgement, common humanity, [[isolation (psychology)|isolation]], [[mindfulness]], and over-identification. Neff recommends this scale for ages 14 and up with a minimum 8th grade reading level.<ref name=":2"/>
Presented on a [[Likert scale]], ranging from 1 (almost no self-compassion) to 5 (constant self-compassion), those completing the SCS are able to gain insight on how they respond to themselves during a struggle or challenging time.<ref name="Van Dam"/>
A shorter, Dutch version of the SCS scale has been developed that uses 24 items.<ref name="Van Dam"/>
=== Short form === The short version of the Self-Compassion Scale (SCS-SF) consists of 12 items and is available in Dutch and English.<ref name=":1" /> Research reveals that the short form scale can be used competently as a substitute for the long form scale.<ref name=":1">{{cite journal | last1 = Raes | first1 = F. | last2 = Pommier | first2 = E. | last3 = Neff | first3 = K. D. | last4 = Van Gucht | first4 = D. | year = 2011 | title = Construction and factorial validation of a short form of the Self-Compassion Scale | url = | journal = Clinical Psychology & Psychotherapy | volume = 18 | issue = 3| pages = 250–255 | doi=10.1002/cpp.702| pmid = 21584907 }}</ref> A study conducted at the University of Leuven, Belgium concluded that when examining total scores, this shorter version provides an almost perfect correlation with the longer version.<ref name=":1" />
=== Six-factor model === Neff's scale proposes three interacting components of self-compassion, which are each composed of two opposite facets. The first dimension is self-kindness versus self-judgment. Self-kindness refers to one's ability to be kind and understanding of oneself, whereas self-judgement refers to being critical and harsh towards oneself. The second dimension is common humanity versus isolation. Common humanity refers to one's ability to recognize that they are part of a related group of others and that suffering is part of the human condition. The third dimension is mindfulness versus over-identification. Mindfulness refers to one's awareness and acceptance of painful experiences in a balanced and non-judgmental way.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://self-compassion.org/the-three-elements-of-self-compassion-2/|title = Self-Compassion|date = 2015|accessdate = 3 August 2015|website = |publisher = |last = Neff|first = Kristin}}</ref> Neff describes these three dimensions interacting to enhance and engender one another.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = Self-Compassion: An Alternative Conceptualization of a Healthy Attitude Toward Oneself|last = Neff|first = Kristin|date = 2003|journal = Psychology Press|doi = 10.1080/15298860309032|pmid = |volume=2|issue = 2|pages=85–101|citeseerx = 10.1.1.616.6302}}</ref>
=== Criticisms of Neff's scale === Currently, Kristin Neff's Self-Compassion Scale is the only self-report instrument used to measure self-compassion. Although it is widely accepted as being a reliable and valid tool to measure self-compassion, recent research has posed questions regarding the scale's generalizability and its use of a six-factor model.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|title = A Reconsideration of the Self-Compassion Scale's Total Score: Self-Compassion versus Self-Criticism|last = Lopez|first = Angelica|date = 20 July 2015|journal = PLOS ONE|doi = 10.1371/journal.pone.0132940|pmid = 26193654|volume=10|issue = 7|pages=e0132940|pmc=4508060}}</ref>
==== Generalizability ==== The generalizability of Neff's Self-Compassion Scale can be questioned; although the scale is used to measure self-compassion in the general population and has been translated into many languages, the scale itself has mostly been tested on college students.<ref name=":3" />
==== Six-factor model ==== A recent study performed by Angélica López et al. examined the factor structure, reliability, and construct validity of Neff's Self-compassion Scale using a large representative sample from the general population. The study consisted of 1,736 participants and used both a confirmatory factor analysis (CFA), and an exploratory factor analysis (EFA) to determine if Neff's six-factor structure could be replicated.<ref name=":3" />
Lopez's study could not replicate the six-factor structure of Neff's Self-compassion Scale, but rather suggested a two-factor model of the scale, created by grouping the positive and negative items separately. Lopez's study also suggests it is important to view self-compassion and self-criticism as being distinct from one another, traits that Neff's Self-compassion Scale assumes are opposites. Lopez's study makes it clear that there is room for further research into the validity of the six-factor structure used by Neff's Self-compassion Scale.<ref name=":3" />
== Exercises == Self-compassion exercises generally consist of either a writing exercise, role-playing, or introspective contemplation, and are designed to foster self-kindness, mindfulness, and feelings of common humanity. Self-compassion exercises have been shown to be effective in increasing self-compassion, along with increases in self-efficacy, optimism, and mindfulness.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|title = Meeting Suffering With Kindness: Effects of a Brief Self-Compassion Intervention for Female College Students|journal = Journal of Clinical Psychology|date = 2014-01-01|volume = 70|issue = 9|doi = 10.1002/jclp.22076|pmid = 24691680|first = Elke|last = Smeets|first2 = Kristin|last2 = Neff|first3 = Hugo|last3 = Alberts|first4 = Madelon|last4 = Peters|pages=794–807}}</ref> These exercises have also been shown to decrease rumination.<ref name=":0" /> In individuals who were vulnerable to depression, one week of daily self-compassion exercises lead to reduced depression up to three months following the exercise, and increased happiness up to six months following the exercise, regardless of the pre-exercise levels of happiness.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = The benefits of self-compassion and optimism exercises for individuals vulnerable to depression|journal = The Journal of Positive Psychology|date = 2010-09-01|issn = 1743-9760|pages = 377–389|volume = 5|issue = 5|doi = 10.1080/17439760.2010.516763|first = Leah B.|last = Shapira|first2 = Myriam|last2 = Mongrain}}</ref>
=== How would you treat a friend? === This exercise asks the user to imagine that they are comforting a close friend who is going through a tough situation. The user is then asked to compare and contrast how they react internally to their own struggles, and to endeavour applying the same loving kindness to themselves that they would apply to a friend.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Neff|first1=Kristin|title=Exercise 1: How would you treat a friend?|url=http://self-compassion.org/exercise-1-treat-friend/|website=self-compassion.org|accessdate=26 July 2015}}</ref>
=== Self-compassion break === This exercise is to be used during times of acute distress. The user is asked to focus on a stressful event or situation. Then, the user is asked to repeat several prompts to themselves, each of which emphasizes one of the three main tenets of self-compassion: [[mindfulness]], [[common humanity]], and self-kindness.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Neff|first1=Kristin|title=Exercise 1: How would you treat a friend?|url=http://self-compassion.org/exercise-2-self-compassion-break/|website=self-compassion.org|accessdate=26 July 2015}}</ref>
=== Exploring through writing === In this exercise, the user is asked to focus on a facet of themself that they believe to be an imperfection, and that makes them feel inadequate. Once they have brought this issue to mind, they are asked to write a letter to themself from the perspective of an unconditionally loving imaginary friend. The user is then asked to focus on the soothing and comforting feelings of compassion that they have generated for themself.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Neff|first1=Kristin|title=Exercise 3: Exploring self-compassion through writing|url=http://self-compassion.org/exercise-3-exploring-self-compassion-writing/|website=self-compassion.org|accessdate=26 July 2015}}</ref>
=== Criticizer, criticized, and compassionate observer === This exercise asks the user to occupy several "chairs" during the course of the practice. Initially, they are asked to occupy the chair of the self-critic, and to express their feelings of [[self-criticism]]. They are asked to analyze this criticism and make note of its defining characteristics. Then, the user is asked to take the chair of their criticized self, and to imagine verbally responding to their inner critic. Subsequently, the user is prompted to conduct a dialogue between these two aspects of the self, the criticizer and the criticized. Following this, the user is asked to imagine themself as a compassionate observer of this dialogue, and finally the user is asked to reflect upon the experience.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Neff|first1=Kristin|title=Exercise 4: The criticizer, the criticized, and the compassionate observer|url=http://self-compassion.org/exercise-4-criticizer-criticized-compassionate-observer/|website=self-compassion.org|accessdate=26 July 2015}}</ref>
=== Changing your critical self-talk === This exercise is meant to be conducted over several weeks, in the form of recurring reflection on the nature of their self-criticism. Users are asked to aim to notice when they are being self-critical, to react to their self-criticism with compassion, and to reframe the language of their inner critic.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Neff|first1=Kristin|title=Exercise 5: Changing your critical self-talk|url=http://self-compassion.org/exercise-5-changing-critical-self-talk/|website=self-compassion.org|accessdate=26 July 2015}}</ref>
=== Journal === This exercise entails keeping a daily journal for at least one week, and is used to reflect on difficult experiences, self-criticisms, and other stressors. The user is asked to analyze each of these events through the lenses of self-kindness (using gentle, comforting language to respond to the event), mindfulness (awareness of the negative emotions elicited by the situation), and common humanity (how the experience is part of the human condition).<ref>{{cite web|last1=Neff|first1=Kristin|title=Exercise 6: Self-Compassion Journal|url=http://self-compassion.org/exercise-6-self-compassion-journal/|website=self-compassion.org|accessdate=26 July 2015}}</ref>
=== Identifying what we really want === In this exercise, the user is asked to think about the ways that they use self-criticism as a way to motivate themself. Then, the user is asked to try to come up with a kinder and gentler and more caring way of motivating themself to make the desired change, and to try and be aware of how they use self-criticism as a motivational tool in the future.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Neff|first1=Kristin|title=Exercise 7: Identifying what we really want|url=http://self-compassion.org/exercise-7-identifying-really-want/|website=self-compassion.org|accessdate=26 July 2015}}</ref>
=== Taking care of the caregiver === This exercise prompts the user to engage in meaningful self-care on a regular basis, and to practice these techniques while they are actively caring for others.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Neff|first1=Kristin|title=Exercise 8: Taking care of the caregiver|url=http://self-compassion.org/exercise-8-taking-care-caregiver/|website=self-compassion.org|accessdate=26 July 2015}}</ref>
== Self-forgiveness as an element == Self-forgiveness is an element of self-compassion that involves releasing self-directed negative feelings. Research has found that self-forgiveness promotes greater overall well-being, specifically higher self-esteem and lower neuroticism.<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|url = |title = Self-Forgiveness versus Excusing: The Roles of Remorse, Effort, and Acceptance of Responsibility|last = Fisher|first = Mickie|date = 2006|journal = Psychology Press|doi = 10.1080/15298860600586123|pmid = |volume=5|issue = 2|pages=127–146}}</ref>
=== Pro-social behavior === When self-directed negative feelings are a result of negative past action, self-forgiveness does not mean ignoring or excusing offenses, but rather practicing self-compassion while taking full responsibility for past action. In this way, self-forgiveness may increase people's willingness to repent for wrongdoing.<ref name=":4" /> Despite this research, there is not yet a clear link between self-forgiveness and pro-social behavior. It would seem that accepting responsibility for negative actions leads to pro-social behavior, and coupling acceptance with self-forgiveness increases this effect.<ref name=":4" />
== Self-acceptance as an element == Self-acceptance is an element of self-compassion that involves accepting oneself for who and what they are. Self-acceptance differs from [[self-esteem]] in that self-esteem involves globally evaluating one's worth. Self-acceptance means accepting the self despite flaws, weaknesses, and negative evaluations from others.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Unconditional Self-Acceptance and Psychological Health|last = Chamberlain|first = John|date = 2001|journal = Journal of Rational-Emotive & Cognitive-Behavior Therapy|doi = |pmid = }}</ref>
==Mindfulness ==
===History === The concept of [[mindfulness]] and self-compassion has been around for over 2500 years, and is rooted in Eastern traditional [[Buddhism|Buddhist]] philosophy and Buddhist meditation.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Cigolla | first1 = F. | last2 = Brown | first2 = D. | year = 2011 | title = A way of being: Bringing mindfulness into individual therapy | url = | journal = Psychotherapy Research | volume = 21 | issue = 6| pages = 709–721 | doi = 10.1080/10503307.2011.613076 | pmid = 21943184 }}</ref><ref name=":02">{{Cite journal|title = A Pilot Study and Randomized Controlled Trial of the Mindful Self-Compassion Program|journal = Journal of Clinical Psychology|date = 2012-01-01|volume = 69|issue = 1|doi = 10.1002/jclp.21923|pmid = 23070875|first = Kristin D.|last = Neff|first2 = Christopher K.|last2 = Germer|pages=28–44|citeseerx = 10.1.1.362.7685}}</ref> In Buddhist philosophy, mindfulness and compassion is considered to be two wings of one bird, with each concept overlapping one another but producing benefits for wellbeing.<ref name=":02" /> The word Mindfulness is the English translation of the word Vipassan, which a combination of two words Vi, meaning in a special way and Passana, to observe, hence implying to observe in a special way.<ref>Nehra, D. K., Nehra, S., & Dogra, R. (2012). Positive psychological functioning with mindfulness based stress reduction (MBSR) program. ''Biopsychosocial issues in positive health. Delhi: Global Vision Publishing House''. from http://globalvisionpub.com/globaljournalmanager/pdf/1389680520.pdf</ref> [[Compassion]] (karunaa) can be defined as an emotion that elicits the wanting to be free from suffering.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Loving-kindness and compassion meditation: Potential for psychological interventions|url = http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0272735811001115|journal = Clinical Psychology Review|date = 2011-01-01|pmc = 3176989|pmid = 21840289|volume = 31|issue = 7|doi = 10.1016/j.cpr.2011.07.003|first = Stefan G.|last = Hofmann|first2 = Paul|last2 = Grossman|first3 = Devon E.|last3 = Hinton|pages=1126–1132}}</ref> Mindfulness in the context of self-compassion comprises acknowledging one's painful experiences in a balanced way that neither ignores, or ruminates on the disliked characteristics of oneself or life. According to Neff (2012) it is essential to be mindful of one's own personal suffering in order to extend compassion towards one's self. However it is essential to pay attention to self suffering in a grounded way in order to avoid "over-identification".<ref name=":02" /> Mindfulness tends to focus on the internal experience such as sensation, emotion and thoughts rather than focusing on the experiencer. Self-compassion focuses on soothing and comforting the self when faced with distressing experiences.<ref name=":02" /> Self-compassion is composed of three components; self kindness verses self-judgement, a sense of common humanity versus isolation and mindfulness versus over-identification when confronting painful thoughts and emotions.<ref name=":02" />
===Mindfulness-based stress reduction === [[Mindfulness-based stress reduction]] ([[Mindfulness-based stress reduction|MBSR]]), developed by [[Jon Kabat-Zinn]] is a structured group program that uses [[mindfulness meditation]] to relieve suffering associated with physical, [[Psychosomatic Illness|psychosomatic]] and [[psychiatric disorders]].<ref name=":12">{{Cite journal|title = Teaching self-care to caregivers: Effects of mindfulness-based stress reduction on the mental health of therapists in training|journal = Training and Education in Professional Psychology|date = 2007-01-01|volume = 1|issue = 2|doi = 10.1037/1931-3918.1.2.105|first = Shauna L.|last = Shapiro|first2 = Kirk Warren|last2 = Brown|first3 = Gina M.|last3 = Biegel|pages=105–115}}</ref> Mindfulness-based stress reduction therapy seeks to increase the capacity for mindfulness, by reducing the need for self-focused thoughts and emotions that can lead to poor mental health.<ref name=":12" /> The exercise of mindfulness-based stress reduction therapy brings together the elements of meditation and yoga, greater awareness of the unity of mind and body, as well as the ways that the unconscious thoughts, feelings, and behaviors can undermine emotional, physical, and [[spirituality|spiritual]] health.<ref>Mindfullivingprograms.com,. (2015). ''Mindfulness Based Stress Reduction''. Retrieved 2 August 2015, from {{cite web |url=http://www.mindfullivingprograms.com/whatMBSR.php |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-04-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060718065653/http://www.mindfullivingprograms.com/whatMBSR.php |archivedate=2006-07-18 |df= }}</ref> Clinical research from the past 25 years has found that MBSR is efficacious in reducing distress and enhancing individual well-being.<ref name=":12" /> Self-Compassion can play a critical role in mindfulness-based cognitive therapy interventions.<ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|title = Self-Compassion in Clinical Practice|journal = Journal of Clinical Psychology|date = 2013-01-01|volume = 69|issue = 8|doi = 10.1002/jclp.22021|pmid = 23775511|first = Christopher K.|last = Germer|first2 = Kristin D.|last2 = Neff|pages=856–867}}</ref> In the study Shapiro et al. (2005) found that health care professionals who underwent a MBSR program reported significantly increased self-compassion and reduced stress levels compared to the waitlist control group. It was also reported that the increase of self-compassion appeared to reduce stress associated with the program.<ref name=":5" />
===Mindfulness-based cognitive therapy === [[Mindfulness-based cognitive therapy]] (MBCT) is an intervention therapy that combines meditation practices, psycho-education and cognitive behavioral strategies to prevent the relapse or recurrence of [[Major depressive disorder|major depression]].<ref>Segal, Z., Williams, J., & Teasdale, J. (2009). ''Mindfulness-based cognitive therapy for depression'' (pp. 307-312). New York, NY: Guilford Press. </ref> MBCT teaches individuals how to observe their thoughts and feelings by focusing their attention on natural objects, such as breathing and bodily sensations. Individuals are taught how to achieve awareness while holding an attitude of non-judgemental acceptance.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Treatment-resistant Depressed Patients Show a Good Response to Mindfulness-based Cognitive Therapy|journal = FOCUS|date = 2010-01-01|issn = 1541-4094|pages = 120–126|volume = 8|issue = 1|doi = 10.1176/foc.8.1.foc120|pmid = 16797486|pmc = 2808477|first = M.a.|last = Kenny|first2 = J.m.g.|last2 = Williams}}</ref> Within MBCT, mindfulness skills are taught in order to recognize distressing thoughts and feelings, to be aware of these experiences, and utilize acceptance and self-compassion to break up associative networks that may causes a relapse. Self-compassion in response to negative thoughts and feelings is an adaptive process, which validates it as a key learning skill in MBCT.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = How does mindfulness-based cognitive therapy work?|url = http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0005796710001774|journal = Behaviour Research and Therapy|date = 2010-01-01|volume = 48|issue = 11|doi = 10.1016/j.brat.2010.08.003|pmid = 20810101|first = Willem|last = Kuyken|first2 = Ed|last2 = Watkins|first3 = Emily|last3 = Holden|first4 = Kat|last4 = White|first5 = Rod S.|last5 = Taylor|first6 = Sarah|last6 = Byford|first7 = Alison|last7 = Evans|first8 = Sholto|last8 = Radford|first9 = John D.|last9 = Teasdale|pages=1105–1112}}</ref> Self-compassion has been found to be a key mechanism in the effectiveness of mindfulness-based interventions such as mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT).<ref name=":5" /> Kuyken et al. (2010) compared the effect of MBCT with maintenance antidepressants on relapse in depressive symptoms.<ref name=":5" /> They found that mindfulness and self-compassion were increased after MBCT was introduced. They also found that MBCT reduced the connection of cognitive reactivity and depressive relapse, and that the increased self-compassion helped mediate this association.<ref name=":5" />
===Mindful self-compassion therapy === Mindful self-compassion (MSC) therapy is a hybrid therapy consisting of self-compassion and mindfulness practices.<ref name=":02" /> The term mindful is referred to in the MSC program as the basic mindfulness skills which is turning toward painful thoughts and emotions and seeing them as they are without suppression or avoidance which is crucial to the development of self-compassion.<ref name=":02" /> The MSC program however focuses more on self-compassion and sees mindfulness as a secondary emphasis.<ref name=":02" /> MSC teaches both formal (meditation) and informal (daily life) self-compassion practices. In addition there are homework MSC assignments that teaches participants to be kinder to themselves.<ref name=":02" /> The goal of MSC therapy is to provide participants with a variety of tools to increase self-compassion which they can then in turn integrate into their lives.<ref name=":02" /> A study conducted by Neff and Germer (2012) found that compared with the control group, MSC intervention participants reported significantly larger increases in self-compassion, mindfulness, wellbeing and a decrease in depression, stress and anxiety which were maintained for 6 months after the initial intervention.<ref name=":02" />
===Compassion focused therapy === Paul Gilbert (2009) developed [[compassion focused therapy]] (CFT) that teaches clients that, due to how our brains have evolved, anxiety, anger and depression are natural experiences that are occur through no fault of our own.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Common language for psychotherapy procedures: the first 80|doi = 10.13140/2.1.2348.1126}}</ref><ref name=":6">{{Cite journal|title = Introducing compassion-focused therapy|url = http://apt.rcpsych.org/content/15/3/199|journal = Advances in Psychiatric Treatment|date = 2009-05-01|issn = 2056-4678|pages = 199–208|volume = 15|issue = 3|doi = 10.1192/apt.bp.107.005264|first = Paul|last = Gilbert}}</ref> Patients are trained to change maladaptive thought patterns such as "I'm unlovable" and provide alternative self-statements, such as "know for sure that some people love me".<ref name=":02" /> The goal of CFT is to help patients develop a sense of warmth and emotional responsiveness to oneself.<ref name=":02" /> This is achieved through a variety of exercises including visualization, cultivating self-kindest through language by engaging in self-compassionate behaviors and habits.<ref name=":02" /> In CFT self-compassion is utilized through thoughts, images, and attention which is needed to stimulate and develop the contentment, sooth and safeness system.<ref name=":6" />
===Mindfulness skills in dialectical behavior therapy === [[Dialectical behavior therapy]] (DBT), is a derivative of [[cognitive behavioral therapy|cognitive behavior therapy]] that incorporates Eastern meditative practice.<ref name=":42">{{Cite journal|title = Mechanisms of change in dialectical behavior therapy: Theoretical and empirical observations|journal = Journal of Clinical Psychology|date = 2006-01-01|volume = 62|issue = 4|doi = 10.1002/jclp.20243|pmid = 16470714|first = Thomas R.|last = Lynch|first2 = Alexander L.|last2 = Chapman|first3 = M. Zachary|last3 = Rosenthal|first4 = Janice R.|last4 = Kuo|first5 = Marsha M.|last5 = Linehan|pages=459–480|citeseerx = 10.1.1.472.9570}}</ref> DBT is based on a dialectical world view that incorporates the balance and integration of opposing beliefs, particularly in acceptance and change. We accept ourselves as good enough, and we recognize the need for all of us to change and grow.<ref name=":42" /> Unlike MBCT and MBSR therapies, dialectical behavior therapy does not use meditation but less formal exercises, such as individual therapy sessions and group skill sessions.<ref name=":22" /> In general last for approximately a year where participants will engage in weekly individual skill therapy sessions and group skill sessions.<ref name=":22">Baer, R. (2006). ''Mindfulness-based treatment approaches''. Amsterdam: Elsevier, Academic Press.</ref> The skills therapy sessions include four segments; core [[mindfulness]], interpersonal effectiveness, [[Emotional self-regulation|emotion regulation]], and [[distress tolerance]] skills.<ref name=":22" /> Dialectical behaviour therapist recommend developing self-compassion. The basic premise of using self-compassion therapies in DBT is to cultivate a compassionate mind state, defined by feelings of warmth, safety, presence and interconnectedness that can in turn relieve [[emotional dysregulation]].<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Does Self-Compassion Mitigate the Association Between Childhood Maltreatment and Later Emotion Regulation Difficulties? A Preliminary Investigation|journal = International Journal of Mental Health and Addiction|date = 2011-07-20|issn = 1557-1874|pages = 480–491|volume = 9|issue = 5|doi = 10.1007/s11469-011-9340-7|first = Lisa C.|last = Vettese|first2 = Catherine E.|last2 = Dyer|first3 = Wing Ling|last3 = Li|first4 = Christine|last4 = Wekerle}}</ref>
===Mindfulness and related skills in acceptance and commitment therapy === [[Acceptance and commitment therapy]] utilizes behavior change process, mindfulness and acceptance process. ACT, involves non-judgmental awareness and openness to cognitive sensation an emotional experiences.<ref name=":22" /> It also promotes exposure to previously avoided situations that have caused anxiety in order to promote acceptance. The avoidant behavior is treated by having clients observing their thoughts and accepting that their thoughts are not necessarily harmful.<ref name=":22" /> In general ACT strategies are customized to fit each participant so they obtain psycho-education, [[problem solving]] skills and [[psychological flexibility]]. Mindfulness and acceptance exercises skills facilitates the behavioral changes necessary for its user to pursue a life that they feel is vital and meaningful.<ref name=":22" /> Various sources have indicated that acceptance and commitment therapy overlaps with Neff's conceptualization of self compassion particularly the ACT's relational frame theory. The basic theories and concepts underlining ACT, may be relevant and have shown to be parallels and hold similarities found in self-compassion<ref name=":32">{{Cite journal|title = Using acceptance and commitment therapy to increase self-compassion: A randomized controlled trial|url = http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S2212144714000763|journal = Journal of Contextual Behavioral Science|date = 2014-01-01|pmc = 4260406|pmid = 25506545|volume = 3|issue = 4|doi = 10.1016/j.jcbs.2014.09.002|first = James E.|last = Yadavaia|first2 = Steven C.|last2 = Hayes|first3 = Roger|last3 = Vilardaga|pages=248–257}}</ref> The first is ACT perspective and Neff's concept of self-kindness are both linked to self-acceptance. Acceptance of one's painful experiences and hurt is related to kindness to one's self.<ref name=":32" /> Second Neff's conceptualization of self-compassion and ACT both emphasize mindfulness, which is practiced ACT through the concepts of defusion, acceptance, contact with the present moment and the self as a context. Defusion is also used in self-compassion as a means of allowing self-criticisms to pass through the mind with believing, proving them wrong or engaging stance to make these thoughts workable.<ref name=":32" /> In a study conducted by Yadavaia, Hayes & Vilardaga, 2014 test the efficacy of an ACT approach to self-compassion as compared to a waitlist control, the study showed that ACT interventions led to a large increase in self-compassion and psychopathology compared to the waitlist control at post-treatment and two months post intervention.<ref name=":32" />

{{Gnosticism}} The '''Severians''' were a sect of gnostic [[Encratites]]. [[Epiphanius of Salamis|Epiphanius]] supposes their leader [[Severus (Encratite)|Severus]] to have preceded [[Tatian]] (founder of Encratites) but [[Eusebius]], [[Theodoret]], and [[Jerome]] make him Tatian's successor. These latter authorities are followed by most ecclesiastical historians, and the silence of [[Irenaeus]] and [[Hippolytus of Rome|Hippolytus]] regarding Severus renders the later date most probable.
Ephiphanius ascribes to the Severians a belief in the well known Gnostic power [[Demiurge|Ialdaboth]] (Yaldabaoth) who appears in the [[Ophites|Ophite]] system as the first offspring of [[Bythus]] and [[Ennoia]]. The Severians held that Ialdaboth was a great ruler of the powers, that from him sprung the [[Devil]]: that the Devil being cast down to the earth in the form of the serpent produced the vine, whose snake-like tendrils indicate its origin: that the Devil also created woman and the lower half of man.<ref>Dictionary of Sects, Heresies, Ecclesiastical Parties, [[John Henry Blunt]]</ref>
